At-a-Glance: An integrated pest management (IPM) plan cycles organic acids, essential oils, biotechnical methods, and brood interruption to keep varroa below damage thresholds.
Why it Matters: Rotating modes of action slows resistance.
Treating at the right time protects winter bees and reduces virus loads.
Biotechnical options reduce chemical inputs and residue risks.
Objectives: Adopt a written IPM calendar aligned to local flows.
Match treatment to brood status and ambient temperatures.
Verify efficacy post-treatment with a quantitative test.
What Good Looks Like: Pre-winter oxalic acid when broodless or near-broodless.
Formic options when temperatures permit and quick knock-down is needed.
Thymol formulations post-harvest during warm stable periods.
Drone brood removal during build-up as part of biotechnical control.
Step-by-Step: 2) Choose option: oxalic acid (dribble/vapor), formic (pads), thymol (gels/strips), or synthetic where permitted and necessary.
3) Confirm temperature window and colony strength.
4) Apply per label and manufacturer guidance exactly.
5) Mark calendar for removal or follow-up.
6) Re-test 10–14 days after treatment to confirm efficacy.
Seasonality & Climate: Winter: oxalic acid ideal when broodless.
Late summer/early autumn: thymol or formic depending on weather.
Spring build-up: biotechnical methods and careful timing to avoid queen loss.
Data & Thresholds: Target post-treatment reduction >80 percent from baseline count.
Autumn targets are stricter to protect winter bees (often <1–2 percent infestation).
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: High mites during hot spell -> Avoid formic in heat spikes -> Use thymol if within range, or plan brood break + oxalic.
Symptom: Ineffective outcome -> Confirm dosage and exposure time -> Switch mode of action and retest.
Common Pitfalls: Applying outside temperature range causing queen loss or poor efficacy.
Failure to remove strips on time.
Tools & Techniques: OA vaporiser or dribble kit, PPE, timers.
Safety & Compliance: Follow local approvals and labels exactly.
Use PPE for acids and ventilate well.
Communications: Explain to customers why treatment timing protects honey quality and bee health.
Further Reading: NBU treatment temperature ranges and labels.
Peer-reviewed comparisons of OA vapor vs dribble efficacy.
Notes: Keep spare equipment to avoid delaying weather-sensitive windows.
